newsitem.title: AZERBAIJAN: Saipem wins Azeri pipelines tender - AIOC.
newsitem.headline: Saipem wins Azeri pipelines tender - AIOC.

text.p: The multinational oil consortium Azerbaijan International Operating Company (AIOC) on Wednesday declared Saipem SpA of Italy the winner of a $24 million tender to build offshore oil and gas pipelines.

An AIOC news release said Saipem would build a gas pipeline linking the state-owned Oil Rocks offshore drilling platform in the Caspian Sea and AIOC's Chirag-1 platform, and a crude pipeline from Chirag-1 to Baku's Sanchagal terminal.
The gas link would be 47 km (29 miles) long and the oil pipeline would run over 182 km (113 miles).
The release said work on both links would begin in January 1997 and be carried out over a tight schedule. It gave no completion date.
The pipelines are part of AIOC's early oil programme.

AIOC is a 13-member consortium headed by an alliance between British Petroleum and Den Norske Stats Oljeselskap ASA (Statoil). It has an $8 billion project to develop hydrocarbon reserves in the Azeri sector of the Caspian.
The release said the group would produce its first "early" oil in the third quarter of 1997. AIOC president Terry Adams has said production will begin on August 28, 1997.
Early output from the consortium's offshore Azeri, Chirag and deepwater Guneshli fields is targeted at 100,000 barrels per day (bpd), rising to 700,000-800,000 bpd by 2010.
